</citation>     <stdyInfo>       <subject>         <keyword>TEACHING METHODS</keyword>         <keyword>TEACHING DATASETS</keyword>         <keyword>2014</keyword>         <topcClas>Major studies and data</topcClas>         <topcClas>Politics</topcClas>         <topcClas>Society and culture</topcClas>       </subject>       <abstract><p>Abstract copyright UK Data Service and data collection copyright owner.</p>The aim was to make easier to handle datasets from Understanding Society, building a core of common variables from the first three waves but including some other wave-specific information from each wave. The richness of the data, including the combination of ratio/interval data as well as categorical/ordinal data, makes for an effective dataset from which to teach quantitative methods of all kinds. A distinctive feature is the provision of datasets in native R format in addition to those in a statistical format.  The 'parent' dataset (SN 6614 at the UK Data Service) is the definitive guide to the variables, sampling, etc.</abstract>       <sumDscr>         <collDate event="start" date="2009-01-01T00:00:00Z">01 January 2009</collDate>         <collDate event="end" date="2013-07-31T00:00:00Z">31 July 2013</collDate>         <nation>United Kingdom</nation>         <geogCover>UK</geogCover>         <geogUnit>Regions</geogUnit>         <anlyUnit>families and households</anlyUnit>         <anlyUnit>individuals</anlyUnit>         <dataKind>Numeric</dataKind>       </sumDscr>     </stdyInfo>     <method>       <dataColl>         <collMode>Extraction of Data from Understanding Society (SN 6614 at the UK Data Service)</collMode>         <sources />       </dataColl>     </method>     <dataAccs>       <setAvail>         <accsPlac>UK Data Service</accsPlac>       </setAvail>       <useStmt>         <contact><a href="mailto:smckay@lincoln.ac.uk">Stephen McKay, University of Lincoln</a></contact>       </useStmt>     </dataAccs>     <othrStdyMat />   </stdyDscr> </codeBook>
